Buying a commercial truck or trailer for your business is a significant investment. With new semi trucks costing as much as $250,000, youâ€™ll likely have to take out a loan. Fortunately, there are plenty of semi truck financing options available â€” whether you buy new or used.

Like any small-business loan, the best semi truck loan is the least expensive one you can qualify for that meets your needs.

What is semi truck financing?

Semi truck financing refers to a small-business loan thatâ€™s used to buy a commercial truck for your business. Depending on your lender, you may be able to purchase new or used vehicles, such as dump trucks, box trucks, flatbed trucks, service trucks, vans, trailers and more.

Like other types of equipment financing, semi truck loans use the truck you buy as collateral on the loan. This means that if you donâ€™t repay your loan, the lender can take possession of your truck and sell it to recover its losses.

How much do you need?

Once we uncover your personalized matches, our team will consult you on the process moving forward.

How does semi truck financing work?

Semi truck loans are typically structured as normal business term loans. Hereâ€™s how they work:

You receive a lump sum of money.The amount you can borrow depends on the lender. For example, lenders often have different maximum amounts they're willing to let you borrow, and many require a down payment.

You repay the loan, with interest.Repayment terms can range from 12 to 60 months, but may be longer, depending on the type of commercial truck. Payments are usually made on a monthly basis, and interest rates can range anywhere from 5% to 36% APR.

You lose your truck if you fail to make payments.Like a personal auto loan, if you fail to repay your loan on a commercial truck, your lender may repossess it.

Semi truck financing vs. leasing

If youâ€™re in the market for a commercial truck, equipment financing is often a better option than equipment leasing. Big rigs may cover a million miles before they require serious work. That means theyâ€™ll likely remain productive long past a three- or five-year loan repayment term, making financing a potentially more cost-effective solution in the long run.

Still, commercial truck leasing can make sense in the following instances:

  • Youâ€™re just starting out. Qualifying for a commercial truck loan can be difficult if your business lacks a track record. Consider leasing a truck while youâ€™re proving your concept before investing a lot of money into a truck of your own.

  • You need to free up cash. Leases typically come with lower upfront costs. Depending on where you live, you may even be able to spread the sales tax over the leaseâ€™s term, which can result in smaller monthly payments and free up cash flow for your business.Â 

  • Youâ€™re worried about longevity. Long-haulers have long shelf lives. But vehicles like delivery vans may face more wear and tear, and specialty trucks with complex parts may need more frequent repairs. If your trucks are used in direct interactions with customers, you may want consistently new models to make a good impression. Leasing can help in all these cases.

Where to get semi truck financing

There are a number of places where you can get a commercial truck loan to buy your next big rig:

  • Direct semi truck lenders. Direct lenders offer deep expertise in the trucking business. They may also be more flexible compared with other lenders because they lend their own money. In addition to traditional business loans, freight factoring companies work specifically with trucking companies to provide upfront cash in exchange for outstanding invoices.Â 

  • Banks. Although banks offer some of the most competitive interest rates, approvals can be time-consuming and tough.

  • SBA lenders. SBA commercial vehicle loans are a great alternative to bank loans due to their low interest rates and long repayment terms. They often require good credit and a couple years in business.

  • Online lenders. Alternative semi truck lenders generally provide faster funding than banks and have more flexible qualification requirements. These companies may be willing to work with new businesses and borrowers with bad credit, but you should expect higher interest rates.

How to finance a semi truck

1. Determine your down payment

Knowing how much you can afford as a down payment is a good place to start when buying any vehicle. Itâ€™s especially important since commercial trucks can cost six figures â€” even if you buy used.

For example, if a lender requires a 20% down payment on a $100,000 big rig, you would need $20,000 on hand, plus money for soft costs such as taxes, registration and other fees. Some lenders may offer no-money-down options, but youâ€™ll need good credit to be eligible and will pay more overall by financing the entire purchase.

2. Consider monthly loan payment

The monthly loan payment amount is another important consideration. Determining the amount that fits in your budget can be helpful in deciding what loan will work best for you. When estimating the amount of an affordable loan payment, donâ€™t forget to include other costs that will come with the truck, like fuel, maintenance, tires and commercial truck insurance.

3. Review semi truck financing requirements

In addition to thinking about a potential down payment and monthly costs, youâ€™ll also want to consider common business loan requirements, to determine what loans you may qualify for:

  • Credit score. Many lenders want to see a minimum credit score in the mid- to high 600s, but others are more flexible. Typically, a higher credit score will help you access lower interest rates.

  • Time in business. Because commercial truck purchases are often expensive, itâ€™s helpful to have two or more years in business. Some lenders may be able to work with younger businesses, however, if they have good credit or can provide a larger down payment.

  • Annual revenue. Some semi truck financing companies donâ€™t have a minimum annual revenue requirement or donâ€™t disclose one upfront. In general, however, youâ€™ll want to be able to show a lender a strong financial history that demonstrates your ability to repay a loan.

If you have bad credit, you may still be able to finance a semi truck with an online or direct lender. Because the truck itself serves as collateral, these lenders may be more open to approving borrowers with poor credit histories or less time in business. Keep in mind that the lender will own the title and could repossess it if you donâ€™t pay. Like other bad credit business loans, these semi truck financing options will likely be more expensive.

4. Find the truck you want â€” and lenders that will fund it

What kind of truck you need will have a direct impact on financing options. For example, some lenders may have vehicle age or mileage requirements. Others may not finance sleeper cab trucks or private-party purchases. Do you need multiple trucks? A lenderâ€™s maximum funding amount may limit your options.

5. Compare commercial truck loans

You can use multiple types of business loans to finance a semi truck, including those not specifically designed for big rigs. For example, a business line of credit could provide you with fast cash to fix up a truck.

But opting for a semi truck loan will keep that working capital available for other business costs. Plus, the vehicle itself offers built-in collateral for lenders, so it may be easier to qualify for semi truck financing than other options.

6. Gather paperwork and apply

Commercial truck lenders have different application processes and requirements. You should be prepared with details about your company (annual revenue, type of business), the vehicle you want to finance (type of truck, its mileage and age, the seller) and yourself (your credit score, whether you have a commercial driverâ€™s license and how long youâ€™ve had it).

Itâ€™s important to shop around and compare multiple lenders, even if you need funding quickly.

Frequently asked questions

How long can you finance a semi truck?

Typical terms for semi truck financing can range anywhere from 12 to 60 months, or even longer. Ultimately, the repayment terms you receive will vary based on your qualifications, lender and the type of vehicle youâ€™re looking to finance.

What is a good down payment on a semi truck?

Many semi truck lenders require a minimum down payment of 10% to 20%, or more. Although some lenders offer commercial truck financing with no down payment, providing money upfront may help increase your chances of qualifying, as well as help you access better rates and terms.

Can you finance a semi truck without a CDL?

Yes. Some lenders, like Triton Capital, do not require you to have a commercial drivers license, or CDL, to get semi truck financing. Others, however, may require you to have a certain length of time with a CDL.

What credit score is needed to buy a semi truck?

Some semi truck lenders, like Triton Capital, may accept credit scores as low as 580. Others will require scores in the mid- to high 600s, or more. Although you can still get semi truck financing with bad credit, interest rates will likely be higher. The better your credit score, the more likely you are to get the most competitive rates and terms on your loan.

Can I use an SBA loan for semi truck financing?

SBA loans can be used for a variety of purposes and may be an option for semi truck financing. SBA 7(a) loan proceeds can be used to purchase machinery and equipment with maximum loan amounts of $5 million.
